message: paging @simonw :)
What happened to djangopeople.net? I found it a useful resource, but it's been down for a while now. Anybody know who runs/ran it?
It's run by Simon Willison (@simonw). Simon, are you looking for new maintainers?
I'd be willing to help host/maintain it, but if it were to migrate to the common infrastructure, that would be even better.
wouldn't mind adopting that as part of the djangoproject.com infrastructure
I don't know what TLC means but I'd love to help :)
As I recall, it needs a lot of TLC, and there's plenty of room for improvement
I've spoken to @simonw in the past, and he's expressed an interest in having someone else take over the project, and as having it be formally part of the djangoproject.com family
TLC = Tender Loving Care
And if you're keen, jump in. The source is all there; if you fork and get the code working on recent Django, and can add a few choice features, I can help get access to the original data and domain.
The source code is all up on github: https://github.com/simonw/djangopeople.net
that sounds like a nice sprinting idea for djangocong, I'll have a look soon.
(djangocong being the French django conference in Marseille in ~2 weeks: http://rencontres.django-fr.org/2011/ )
Thanks, @freakboy3742. I'll take a look.
@danfairs I'll be watching your github profile :)
@brutasse yes great idea for #djangocong - the code needs to be updated i think but this website is interesting and should be kept up
@brutasse uh-oh :)

@jezdez yeah, maybe the djangoproject.com website should endorse djangopeople as the official place to find django developers but I'm not sure about a merge between both (that'd introduce a huge maintenance burden). I imagined something more like djangosnippets, with an official maintainer
that said, I don't have strong feelings with regard to who maintains it in the end, just that it needs to be maintained at all
sheesh, it's so unmaintained i forgot the url :(
@Gulopine Perhaps we should get @simonw to fold it into lanyrd :)
ah
well, there really is potential with lanyrd though, because there are so many conferences and user groups that are already on there
@danfairs @brutasse Awesome, let me know if you need anything from the deployment side, the current code for djangoproject.com is at https://github.com/django/djangoproject.com
@brutasse well, djangoproject.com already has a team of maintainers, so it would probably be a better bus factor than just one, as we can see it with simon at the moment
we should definitely talk to simon again before that though
Yeah - it was a 0.5 joke!
@jezdez @brutasse For sure.
@freakboy3742 can you remember whether you talked about whether both sites should be integrated with a central user object? I'm worried it'd be a hassle to combine both sites per se
i'm thinking about looking for someone to take over djangoevents.org, and if there's an option to give it to the community at large, i'll look into it
@jezdez that makes sense
@jezdez sure. Maybe it's just that I'm not aware of the size of the team behind the django website. My initial reaction was that it'd eat more core dev time
Agreed - that was the other 0.5... Worth exploring, though I get the impression Simon's time is pretty constrained right now (as is all of our time of course)
er, djangoevents.com
hrm, perhaps for some features, but it's a different scope from lanyrd
anyway, i should start a new topic for djangoevents rather than hijack this

@Gulopine no, there isn't a process of adopting unmaintained projects per se, e.g. the recent modifications on the community section were solely driven by community interest (mostly @justinlilly). but we talked about having a more prominent people/project section for a long time
sorry to get a little off-topic here, but is there a process for community-oriented sites like that in general to be considered as "official" or whatnot?
for one thing, djangoevents includes django releases, community site launches, etc
i wouldn't want an unmaintained project adopted anyway, so i'm working on a maintainer first, then we'll see what happens
@Gulopine cool, sounds like a plan
I think a primary change needed for djpeople.net is to switch to PostGIS/GeoDjango.  The locational stuff right now is a bit hacky.  If someone wants to work on that, I'd be happy to advise.
Also, I have some commits that might be handy here: https://github.com/jdunck/djangopeople.net/commits/master
Mainly porting to Django 1.1 (which was current at the time).
@jdunck if the current code isn't using geodjango, I agree a switch is needed
@jdunck oh right, that makes sense :)
Time allowing, I can look at that - I've now got an existing GeoDjango project under my belt, so I have a reasonable idea of how it works.
@brutasse djpeople predated geodjango and has had minimal maintenance since.
what was the site about?
sounds like it was similiar to workingwithrails?
Handy for finding Django people nearby.
@convy It was pretty simple really - you could register yourself, your location, specialist skills and a brief bio; and it let you search by area.

Worth mentioning is http://django.hiddenhires.com/. Of course that still hasn't launched even though was meant to last July. Hate it when sites never eventuate but they leave them up as is anyway. Same nonsense is happening with some of the new Python web hosting services which have died or are rumoured to have died.
Someone should make it an experiment in OSS participation.. registration should require a pull request :)
@jezdez Authentication stuff has been discussed briefly; mostly as a "hey, wouldn't it be cool if there was a common OAuth signin for all Django community projects, etc"
@freakboy3742 Gotcha, that'd be rad

IIRC there was a call for volunteers at DjangoCon to take the baton on djangopeople.net. I know we offered to help as did a few others at that time. It would be helpful to get some sort of semi-official green light from the DSF and/or core devs before investing time in something like this in order to avoid any confusion about expectations etc.
FWIW I did spend all of about 5 minutes scraping the US page a while back and importing that into SimpleGeo. Worked great! :)

@unbracketed While it's totally cool that you can do that with SimpleGeo - I think there'd also be value in using djangopeople.net as a nice reference 'real site' that uses GeoDjango directly. I think that's a secondary nice-to-have vs. having the site back up and running, of course.
@danfairs I agree, just thought I'd mention it as an option

Quick update, @danfairs and I are trying to get some work done. The idea is to upgrade to django 1.3, add tests, convert the view to class-based views and make use of geodjango when it makes sense. If anyone's interested, please ping us! The repo is at https://github.com/brutasse/djangopeople.net, we're trying to identify the best way to communicate in an open way (convore, mailing-list, IRC?). Also it'd be nice to have some insights from @simonw and @jdunck about the plans you had for the site

Let's try it the wiki way: https://github.com/brutasse/djangopeople.net/wiki. People can add some tasks, suggest ideas and assign tasks to them to let other people know what they're working on. We'll see how it goes :)
@brutasse if you need some help, ping me. Reading the wiki
The wiki should be ok for listing tasks and ideas, but I don't think it's quite appropriate for discussing the design and implemetation of features. Maybe a convore group would be more appropriate?

@ianmlewis I think mailing lists handle threading better - that said, I guess there's nothing stopping us setting up a Convore group, rather than just a single topic. But hey - as long as everyone's in the same place, I don't really care. As long as we're not sending wax tablets through the mail, that is :)
I wish Github had built-in mailing-lists :)
Why use mail when you can link to a convore chat room on the wiki?
@bezidejni You could well be right - though at the moment we're focussing on bringing existing functionality onto 1.3 and GeoDjango.
So, I guess we have a dedicated group now, courtesy of @bezidejni :) https://convore.com/djangopeoplenet-development/ - if you're looking for stuff to do, join us!
@brutasse Request sent.
@micrypt request? Oh well, I think this needs to be a public group. @bezidejni can you adjust the group settings?
Sure, I haven't even noticed I clicked the wrong option :o
